children.value: The first version of Python released in 1991—earlier than the programming language Java. For much of its early existence, Python remained a niche language and did not gain widespread popularity. However, in recent years, the rise and proliferation of big data and artificial intelligence technologies have significantly boosted Python’s popularity. Thanks to its
, Python aligns well with the needs of these emerging technologies, allowing it to surpass many other programming languages and rise rapidly in prominence.

Python was named “Programming Language of the Year” by the well-known TIOBE index in 2010, 2018, 2020, 2021 and 2024. It has consistently ranked among the top three most popular programming languages in both annual and monthly rankings. A popular saying has even emerged online:
Life is short, I use Python.

Python was created by a Dutch programmer Guido van Rossum. During the Christmas holiday in 1989, he decided to develop a new scripting interpreter to pass the time. His goal was to create a successor to the ABC programming language, and thus Python was born.

The name “Python” was chosen not because of the snake, but because Guido van Rossum was a big fan of the BBC television show Monty Python’s Flying Circus. However, since “python” also means a large snake in English, many Python-related tools and books use a snake as their logo or icon.

Python 2.0 was released on October 16, 2000, while Python 3.0 was released on December 3, 2008. Python 3 is not backward-compatible with Python 2 code. Currently, Python 3 is the dominant version, and all Python programs in this book are based on Python 3.
Python is considered one of the most
programming languages. Compared to languages like C, C++, and Java, Python can accomplish the same tasks with significantly less code.

that help programmers easily implement various functionalities. It also provides multiple interfaces that allow seamless integration with other coding lanuages like C, C++, Java, R, Matlab to develop extension modules. For this reason, many people refer to Python as a “glue language.”
math — Python’s built-in library for mathematical functions
random — Python’s built-in library for generating random numbers
numpy — Used for array and matrix operations
pandas — A key tool for handling tabular data and data analysis
matplotlib — A commonly used basic plotting library
seaborn — An advanced visualization library (more beautiful, more focused on statistical graphs) based on matplotlib
scipy — A library for scientific computing
statsmodels — A library for statistical modeling and analysis
PyTorch, TensorFlow — Deep learning libraries commonly used in natural language processing and computer vision
BeautifulSoup, Selenium — Libraries for web scraping

language—functions, modules, numbers, and strings are all treated as objects. It fully supports inheritance, overloading, derivation, and multiple inheritance, and it also allows operator overloading.
in Python programming, Python data types are
An “object” is a data entity in computuer memory that has a unique identity (ID), a type, and a value.
An Python object can have many functions, in which we call the function “method”.
Python is a cross-platform scripting language (a
where codes are intepreted during running).
Compared to compiled languages like C/C++ and Java, its execution speed is slower
. However, as computer processing power continues to increase, Python’s slower speed has gradually become a negligible drawback.
Famous applications developed using Python include:
Douban — A well-known Chinese platform for book, music, and movie reviews
Learning programming is different from studying subjects like math or literacy — you don’t need to memorize code, but you must
ChatGpt, Grok, Gemini, DeepSeek → Ask AI and get detailed answers
→ A global Q&A platform for coding
There are generally several ways to use Python: one is to install
, and the other is to install Python along with the integrated development environment (IDE) like
and a wide range of pre-installed popular librarys, such as NumPy, Pandas, Matplotlib, and Scikit-learn. It also supports other editors like
, IPython, and RStudio. For beginners who are just starting to learn Python,
The specific installation steps will not be detailed here — please visit the official websites to download and install the required software.
When writing programs, variables are often used to store data. In Python, a variable is assigned using an equals sign (

name = "Tim Cook" # name is string varaible
print(name)

mark = 75 # mark is numeric varaible
print(mark)
only contain letters, digits and underscores (
A name cannot begin with a number
A variable name cannot start with a digit.
Names are case-sensitive, meaning “name” and “Name” are treated as two different variables.

Name = "Donald Trump"
print(Name)

_score = 55 # this is a valid naming
print(_score)
The principle of naming is that the
name should clearly indicate the meaning of the variable/function/class
, making it easier to debug and for others to read your code. Sometimes, a variable name may consist of multiple words. In such cases, you can:
Capitalize the first letter of each word, e.g., “AverageScore”
The second style is also known as Camel Case Naming, because the capital letters resemble the humps of a camel (Camel Case Naming is usually used for naming a class in Python).
When typing a variable, function, method name, you can use the
key to get suggestions or enable auto-completion in the editor.
Reserved words, also known as keywords, are identifiers that are predefined and reserved by the programming language. When writing code, programmers
cannot use reserved words as variable names

1name = "chen"  # starts with a digit
class = 10       # 'class' is a reserved keyword
user-name = "Donald"  # contains a hyphen
Python allows assigning the same value to multiple variables in a single line:

a = b = c = 50 # assign same values for 3 variables
print(a, b, c)
We can assign different values to multiple variables simultaneously:

x, y, z = 1, 2, "Python"
print(x, y, z)
Swapping two variables is easy in Python:

a, b = 6, 8
a, b = b, a
print(a, b)
Deleting a variable from the computer memory can be done by using the keyword
Operators are used to perform operations on values and variables. The operators of Python are given by the following table.

# Variables
a = 10
b = 3

# Addition
print("Addition:", a + b)  

# Subtraction
print("Subtraction:", a - b) 

# Multiplication
print("Multiplication:", a * b)  

# Division
print("Division:", a / b) 

# Floor Division
print("Floor Division:", a // b)  

# Modulus
print("Modulus:", a % b) 

# Exponentiation
print("Exponentiation:", a ** b)

b += a # equals b = a + b

are the membership operators that test whether a value or variable is in a sequence.
Printing output in Python is straightforward with the

# output multiple variables
name = "Alice"
age = 20
city = "London"
print(name, age, city)
function is used to take user input. It returns the form of a string by default.
name = input("please input your name：") # take user input to the variable "name"

When writing programs, it’s often necessary to add comments in the code to explain or annotate certain parts, indicate the author or date, and improve the readability of the program. Comments are not executed by the computer. In Python, there are two ways to add comments:
Multi-line comments: Use two sets of triple single quotes (
), with the comment content placed between them
print("hello") # this is a single line comment

"""
This is 
a multi line comment
"""
print("hello")
Many code editors provide shortcut keys for commenting code. For example, in Spyder, use
When debugging a program, comments are sometimes used to temporarily disable parts of the code that are not relevant to the debugging process, making it easier to test and troubleshoot.
Sometimes, when a line of code is too long and needs to be split across multiple lines, you can use the backslash (
) at the end of the line to indicate line continuation:

print('these codes are \
too long.') # line breaking
must not be immediately followed by a comment.

When importing the library，the name of the library is
is also used to abbreviate the package name:
Then, when using methods from NumPy in your code, we can simply use np instead of numpy.
np.log10(200) # use the method log10 from numpy
to import specific methods from a library. In this situation, there is no need to put the name of library in front of the method.

from numpy import sqrt # import the method sqrt from the numpy library

sqrt (200) # no need to put the name of the library in front of the method
to import all the methods in a library.
In this way, all methods from the library can be used directly without needing to prefix them with the library name.

At the end of each chapter, this book introduces some of Python’s standard libraries. These built-in libraries, which require no additional installation, provide many commonly used functionalities such as file operations, mathematical computations, network communication, data processing, and more.

is a built-in Python library containing mathematical methods, providing 4 mathematical constants and 44 mathematical methods. These methods include: math constants, number representation methods, power and logarithmic methods, trigonometric methods and special methods.

children.value: Input the following codes in your Python editor and run.

# draw circles

import turtle

turtle.pensize(2)
turtle.circle(20)
turtle.circle(40)
turtle.circle(60)
turtle.circle(80)
turtle.done()
